job_title: Vice President Facilities Management in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Providing Healthcare Services to the Brooklyn community. A rewarding long-term career.
cons: State Budget and Procurement Process is a challenge. State hiring practice does not lend itself to succession planning.

review_title: Toxic culture, strong union that does not care about employees
pros: Reliable salary, good health insurance benefits (especially for people who have worked 10+years)
cons: Few incentives for performance create an environment where some people do little while others contribute much more. Some people get promotions even though they constantly fail projects, others do not even though they pick up the slack. Lots of preferential treatment. Also, working from home has been a success even though upper management of university keeps trying to get employees back to the office. Why?

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Health benefits, job stability, salary ok
cons: Toxic environment, very little support from administrators, no compensation for upgrade in degrees, no nurse educators to help nurses to improve their skills

job_title: Human Resources Administrative Assistant and Social Media Marketing in Brooklyn, NY
pros: There are so many good things about this company. Within the Alumni Association, you have access to many other departments that fall under the SUNY Downstate Medical Center/University umbrella. The best part of my former job was that I learned a lot, and got the chance to meet many people. I had a great boss in Kristian Balgobin. He was one of a kind.
cons: The pay for the position that I held was on the low end. Once I resigned from this role, I noticed that they raised the salary by $10,000. Another con is the fact that since it is a small office, the Executive Director has full control over the office staff without an HR department acting as checks and balances. This is very dangerous in the workplace. There is a board that fills in the gaps, but this is not quite the same. I felt like I was not wanted in my position once the new Executive Director came into the role. My previous boss and I got along really well, and to this day has offered to write me a letter of recommendation. If there was a proper HR department, these matters could of been addressed with them if something was to pop up.

pros: They give you a good work life balance

cons: Unprofessionally run school and hospital.

review_title: A challenging work environment with a talented and committed staff serving an adult population contending with HIV/AIDS
pros: A truly diverse and committed staff of various disciplines that recognize the value that each discipline provides to the overall medical and mental health treatment needs of the patients we serve.
cons: The grant funded services can be restrictive with their performance based targets that need to be met and this can cause a level of stress that needs to be proactively managed.

review_title: Great place to grow in the medical field.
job_title: Nursing Station Clerk in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Stable secure position.  Lots of staff willing to help as long as you are pleasant.  Great exposure to multiple aspects of the medical field.  Benefits are top-notch.  Union shop.  Encouraging environment for staff education.
cons: Multiple superiors to make happy, sometimes with conflicting orders.  Sometimes you meet a sociopath or psychopath or three.

review_title: Do not work here if you're looking for a career
pros: The benefits and accrual of vacation and sick leave… that's all!
cons: Horrible attitudes, respect is only based off of how many degrees you have and even though the cost of living in Brooklyn has risen tremendously, the thought of getting a raise… shouldn't even be a thought in this place.  There's no opportunity for growth because they mostly choose candidates externally than those internally that has been working there for years.  Not disgruntled, just being completely honest.

pros: New York State takes care of its own; the benefits are hard to beat. If you're lucky, you'll get to work with some of the smartest doctors, at least the ones who haven't high-tailed it to greener ($) Manhattan.
cons: They gave up their (sincere) effort at trying to inspire a sense of esprit de corp years (and at least two Presidents) ago. The only motivation management uses now is fear. When I visit my old workmates (what few are still left) they look like concentration camp survivors.

pros:
- Multicultural environment
- Meet interesting people
- Flexible hours (depends on the department and employer)
- Can learn a lot if you take initiative
- Helpful and friendly staff (many of them, at least)
cons:
- Not much room for advancement
- Research quality is great in some labs and not so much in others
- Not a lot of funding in the basic sciences

pros: Good salary and you can learn a lot.  The medical and dental benefits are not outstanding but just OK compared to other colleges.
cons: I don't know where to start.  The buildings are rundown.  The offices are worse.  I had an a/c in my office that would spit black dust around the room.  The elevators were often out of order.  The workers, in general, are disgruntled and don't see to want to work for their salaries and aren't pushed to do so.  Therefore, most work falls to those that have a good work ethic and they are drowned in it. And then, they're micromanaged.  Not a well organized or managed institution.

pros: PTO is great, but management makes you feel guilty to take a day off.  They allow overtime however, it is expected of you to work more hours and they get pissed off if you have to leave
cons: Management and HR work together. If you are in within your rights, it will be held against you.  This is a biased place and there is favoritism beyond belief.  There are no raises or bonuses and you are expected to do more than your actual job.  When something is missed or incorrect in your job performance it is not seen as overwhelmed but its noted as being neglectful.  RUN

pros: Some nice people and the future could be amazing.
cons: Out in the middle of nowhere, check the benefits before starting (Not your average company) The Research Foundation is separate from SUNY downstate. Also do some background checks on some people you maybe working with! Just one more item, don't leave late if you are taking the MTA.

review_title: It was great working at SUNY Downstate Medical Center.
pros: I like meet new people and help the patient when I would. Sometime the nurses or nurse assisting would be busy with other patient and patient may need a blank or a pillow the small thing .I really enjoy my work.
cons: The bad part about working in SUNY Downstate Medical Center when a patient pass away. It was new to me I was friend with them. Some of them had no family to visit them.

pros: State pension system, if one should take TIAA-CREF or ERS (Employee Retirement System), benefits and savings is excellent.  Matching of contributions are excellent and retirement system is reasonable for a short term employment of 10 years.
cons: Upper management leadership is confused and inexperienced for a multi-funcional campus.  In particular, education, research and patient care.  All suffer when the attention is constantly changing and directed toward and away from each other.

review_title: A fun experiment not to be repeated...
pros: Salary, benefits are great. Doing something as basic as answering an email promptly will garner you extraordinary praise.
cons: The senior management is a nightmare on wheels. Anyone with talent or drive is leaving this place like it's on fire. If you're innovative or ambitious, stay away. This place is stuck in 1985. Projects started years ago have still not finished. There is zero digital presence. There is no interest in updating skills.

pros: PTO, Medical Benefits other then that Downstate/ University Physician's of BKLYN have nothing to offer you.
cons: NO ROOM FOR ADVANCEMENT, NO BONUSES, NO RAISES. If you are one of the few good employees, the ones who are over achievers and have good work ethic you will be taken advantage of. Good work gets rewarded with more work and there are no incentives. Poor management, employees are not held accountable, lack of motivation of desire, indecent employees, safety hazards, lack of training, unorganized, dirty, outdated equipment, no enough funding or funds in the budget to improved quality of care and quality of the workplace.

job_title: Staff Assistant II in Brooklyn, NY
pros: I have worked here for nearly 23 years and it has afforded me extremely growth in managerial and administrative experience.
cons: No opportunity to elevate to the next level. Enormous amount of changes departmentally and within the institution that are not positive changes.

review_title: Difficult environment, interesting patients and pathology, old boys network
pros: Patients are very interesting and you can learn a lot from them.  These patients don't have any other options so in many cases you are the only thing saving their life.
cons: Extremely difficult work environment due to support staff and leadership.  Compensation is extremely variable even amongst colleagues breeding resentment.

pros: The benefits are great, if you have a passion for helping people and want to make a difference in the community.
cons: Management can be unprofessional, undermining & demeaning at times.  A lot of culture clashes as well and a tremendous amount of patience is needed to deal with management!

pros: This was an amazing environment. I worked in a small office but my coworkers always made each day brighter. I dealt with incoming residents and helped to approve their documentation.
cons: We were often understaffed to complete the sizable job we had. Doctors were often very pleasant to work with.

job_title: Senior Research Support Specialist in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Some kind people to work with.
cons: This place is a mess.  The bureaucracy is insanely complex and difficult to work with, my lab directors were monsters who liked to harass me in the middle of the night (when I was NOT WORKING), and the pay for an entry level position was abysmal.  There are some nice people there if you wade through it all, but mostly just a terrible place to be employed.

review_title: Get some incredible clinical experience and work with some of the best students and residents but get vested and move on

pros: The first four years of employment was great with the former Administrator. Staff was afforded opportunity to improve knowledge base through paid seminars and conferences. This was later cut due to budgetary constraints.

Mismanagement of resources and personnel, acquisition of facilities which drained the institution financially, leading to wholesale downsizing of staff.
Inability to get rid of non-productive employees due to union protection

review_title: good for the community the people need it

review_title: SUNY Downstate used to be a good place to work, now it is more like a prison
pros: Downstate has some of the most dedicated professionals that I have ever met. I have many good friends at Downstate.
cons: Since PTS took over there seems to be no future in working for Downstate. People are looked down upon and we are made to feel as if we have nothing to contribute. This Hospital is being sucked dry.

review_title: Decent experience but tough since its state run so it's more run down and less efficient than the private hospitals.
pros: Cheaper tuition. Dorm right across the street. Gym across the street. Really nice classmates.
cons: More run down. More difficult to do well in since they have very high expectations from their students.

pros: I enjoyed work at Long Island College Hospital.  My years there were both challenging, growth oriented and career driven.
cons: The downside is the after 150 plus years in business, the Hospital closed.  Leaving many people out of work and no Hospital for the community to go for healthcare.

review_title: Multicultural but frustrating administration- take care of great patients,
pros: great patient population- interesting care challenges, state benefits are generous, most of the employees are nice and the culture is generally easygoing.
cons: inflexible, boneheaded administration. Unclear what the long term plan or goal is.

pros: As a state employee there are great benefits (healthcare, leave time, union). Many nice and interesting people.
cons: Very hard to get things done with the bureaucratic culture. Many grumpy, rude people, as well. The Sodexo run cafeteria served straight up gruel. It was not good food.
